awd_titl_txt: CPS: Medium: Image Guided Robot-Assisted Medical  Interventions
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of this project is to develop a novel cyber-physical system (CPS) for performing multimodal image-guided robot-assisted minimally invasive surgeries (MIS). The approach is based on: (1) novel quantitative analysis of multi-contrast data, (2) control that uses this information to maneuver conformable robotic manipulators, while adjusting on-the-fly scanning parameters to acquire additional information, and (3) human-information/machine-interfacing for comprehensive appreciation of the physical environment. 

The intellectual merit arises from the development of: (1) a CPS that relies on "real" and "real-time" data, minimizing parametric and abstracted assumptions, extracts and matures information from a dynamic physical system (patient and robot) by combining management of data collection (at the physical sensor site) and data analysis (at the cyber site), (2) "smart sensing", to control data acquisition based on disruptive or situation altering events, (3) control coordination by interlacing sensing, control and perception, and the incorporation of steerable tools.

The societal impact arises from contributions to a leap in MIS: from "keyhole" visualization (i.e., laparoscopy) to in-situ real-time image guidance, thereby enabling a wider range of MIS. This will directly benefit patients and their families (faster recovery/reduced trauma). Economic impact arises from the cost-effectiveness of MIS to the health care system, faster patient return to the workplace, and technology commercialization. The project will integrate research and education, diversity and outreach, by enhancing current and introducing new research-intensive courses in Cyber-physical Systems, Medical Imaging and Medical Robotics, and dissemination via trans-institutional collaborations, a comprehensive web site, multimedia web-seminars, and distribution to high schools.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

por.por_cntn:
The overall goal of the project is to develop software and hardware components and integrating them into a functional CPS for performing Multimodal Image-guided RObot-assisted Surgeries (MIROS). Examples of such minimally invasive procedures are biopsies, ablations and localized delivery o therapeutic agents. The motivation and impact of this project is based on the premise that performing interventions with real-time Magnetic Resonance Imaging (rtMRI) guidance will have substantial impact in healthcare by improving patient outcome and procedural efficiency.

 

The MIROS system by integrating robotics and MRI guidance offers access to the patient inside the MRI scanner allowing the clinician to “operate while imaging” for accurately maneuvering the tool on the fly. In contrast to current multi-step or dual-modality clinical processes, use of an MR-compatible manipulator has several advantages that benefit procedure workflow and patient outcome: 1) placement of the tool using the same modality used to locate the lesion; 2) no movement or relocation of the patient between imaging and interventional sessions; 3) immediate access to a variety of contrast mechanisms before, during, and after the intervention; and 4) improved accuracy, reduced time and cost, easier scheduling, and improved patient comfort. This would transform the practice of interventional medicine by improving current procedures and introducing new diagnostic and therapeutic interventions to ameliorate medical conditions of high impact to patients, their families, and society. With faster patient recovery, the MIROS technology will reduce the overall cost of healthcare and enable a faster return of the patient to the workforce, thereby having a potentially high broader impact.

 

Intellectual merit of this project originates from its challenging nature. The MIROS system entailed the development of new technologies in a wide range of disciplines, including new methods for collecting and processing very fast MRI data and processing of those data in real-time to extract valuable information needed by the operating physician for controlling the robot on-the-fly to reach the targeted lesion inside the patients body with high accuracy and without harming vital or healthy tissue. This required the development of methods for providing this information to the physician in an intuitive way that was addressed by introducing virtual reality means and ultrafast data processing. Along the path the develop MIROS we further developed new robotic technology that is robust and of low-cost. This new robotic actuation technology has applications far beyond healthcare and high potential impact to manufacturing, aerospace and oil/gas industries. An integral part of this project was to disseminate this research to young students to both educating them in the fields of robotics and medial imaging, as well as motivate them to further pursue those disciplines. Overall, we anticipate that the technology invented and developed for the MIROS project will have far reaching impact in healthcare, education, research and economy.


Last Modified: 07/12/2016
Modified by: Nikolaos Tsekos
